comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: I wonder if this is related to the assassination of Sean Hales and Padraig O Maile on December 7 1922. There was also a substantial arms dump found in Blessington Street during the search for their killers. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60A13FA345A1B7A9...

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] it could be but the photo doesn't look like anywhere near Kildare Street or Blessington Street. (btw Ó Máille survived the shooting and went on to become a Senator, ironically as a member of Fianna Fáíl)

comment.author: 33577523@N08
77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Ah sorry, I assumed the shooting took place close to Leinster House. Ormonde Quay/Capel Street puts us back to Great Strand Street as a possibility.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Possibly the corner of Great Strand Street and Swift's Row. The advertisement bedecked wall could conceivably be the side wall of the Printing Works maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,715467,734353,7,9 Unfortunately none of the buildings in that area have survived so there are no clues other than the proportions of the street and the direction of the light. maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&ll=53.346817,-6.265737&...

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: I think I may have found a clue! This photo by the same photographer dated February 1922 is of a fire at Cahill printers on Ormond Quay. catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000194511

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: I think if Mr Hogan was alive today he'd tell us he took his photograph at the bottom of Hill Street where it meets Parnell Street.(what was then Great Britain Street.) Streetview The curb gradiants match. Parnell St is narrow at this point--- only allowing room for a single tram track. OSI Same number of bricks between windows as now. Its gable has a bill board and marks of historical signage mirroring what we see above. Gable Streetview. The "Nugget" shop has fresher brickwork.Its cills are thinner and appear to be made of concrete all suggesting a relatively recent reconstruction....and nice to see timber sashes.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03/] I think you got it, well done.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Looks very like it, alright. It'd be nice if you could find some clincher or other.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: How're we doing for other photos of Parnell street in the catalogue?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: This one certainly doesn't disprove the theory: catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000268540

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The mystery thing bottom right is a louvred vent of some sort. Was there ever a public bog on the suggested corner?

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] There's the hip roof above the bill board in your link.
In the 1911 there are 9421 entrys for 'Great Britain Street' alone ( DED Rotunda) !!!!! -- so looking for the 'Nugget' man would be a bit of an number.

comment.author: 8468254@N02

comment.author: 47290943@N03

If there was a cobbler/boot seller there, it'd be really good...

comment.author: 91549360@N03

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] No worries. No's 135 and 134 Parnell St.
Hill Street blues if I'm wrong. :)

comment.author: 7517351@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] At first I wasn't convinced, But having looked at both in detail I would say I'm 99% sure you are correct. Each window lower is 29 bricks high and the upper windows are 9 bricks above the arch of the lower ones. There is also a half brick above the closest window which matches up exactly with that of the existing building. Well done. :)

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
I am not convinced with the Parnell Street / Hill Street solution. The "Boot Polish" building is only half the height of the main building. 

With all the development in Dublin since the 1920's it is very unlikely that all 3 buildings survive as we see them in the Photo.

comment.author: 7517351@N05
comment._content: The boot polish building is clearly a lot newer than the corner building in current street view pics though. I suppose it's possible that the building was replaced or rebuilt at some point after this photo was taken.

comment.author: 98201178@N06
comment._content: the old house

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Your hunch is right...Can you please look up pages 5 of both the Irish Independent and Freeman's Journal for Monday 8th January 1923.--- You will find that there's a very sad story behind our photograph........ probably taken the next day. The address given matches the topography (curb gradients and corner) and it being a tram street. Both papers also run ads for Robinson Crusoe. I was close.......sorry, but thanks for all the brick counting [http://www.flickr.com/photos/richiesphotos] ...Regards Owen
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03/9178610310/][http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03/9176395265/]

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: "Corner of Summerhill and Langrish Place" ...-OSI Nothing remains Streetview [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03/9178612810/]

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Well Done - fantastic spotting, nobody else was even close. I was thinking that this would remain unsolved for a long while.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Thanks...I was 180mts out the first time.There's an account of the fire on page 177 in this Google book The Dublin Fire Brigade:---- A History of the Brigade, the Fires and the Emergencies. Some kids threw a banger into the shop which exploded a barrel of Parafin and burnt the house down. Five people, including some young children, were killed.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Well done [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] - that's a particularly unhappy corner of the city. There was a double gangland murder there a couple of years ago. www.independent.ie/irish-news/drug-lord-shot-dead-in-city...

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] And there was the car bomb in May ' 74, just down the road, when 10 people were killed.

comment._content: Nice!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Well done [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] ! I only see one Nugget-related occupation on Summer Hill in the 1911 Census, on Summer Row: Finnigan Thomas 27 Male Head of Family Roman Catholic Dublin City Bootmaker Read and write Widower. The .pdf indicates that the house number on form B is 6, consistent with the OS map, although the map does not indicate exactly where Summer Row is.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: This newspaper report gives Mrs. Brophy as one of the casualties. Here are the Brophy's in 1911 (in house number 5). Maybe not the Mrs. Brophy who died, given that Brophy is her maiden name...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] As others have said, hugely well done for plugging away at this one, and thank you for solving our mystery. I apologise that I couldn't get to the newspapers today. I'll try to do that tomorrow...
